I have read carefully all the posts so far a=
nd I tend to agree with
Robert. I am wonder whether I miss something import=
ant too.
I want to be clear, so I will take one step backward. What is the =
MAIN
purpose of JUnit? The answer is to be able to write AUTOMATIC unit
tes=
t. Unit test should be written is the correct way, that is
correctly design=
. This has nothing to do with logging. Making unit
test AUTOMATIC contradic=
t using logging.

<you can skip the this paragraph>
I want to step aside fo=
r a while. Let assume that you're not using
JUnit at all and write small ma=
in function to test. I don't want to
counter why you shouldn't do this, let=
 focus on what tools you do use
in this approach. In the most cases you wil=
l add System.out both to
the code and to the main. If you're using C++, for=
 instance, you will
use preprocessor to switch on or off these output to th=
e console. More
advance option will be to use logging mechanism and to chan=
ge it
configuration depends on the environment your program run (that is to=

turn on many of your log statement only in development). Everything is
gre=
at until your program is actually fails. Again, from the experience
it is a=
lmost always the case that existing System.outs are not enough,
that you ne=
ed more information or you should add some more output
early in the code. S=
o, in this point you have to option to run your
program AGAIN with debugger=
 or to add more System.outs and to run it
as is. In both cases it can be th=
e case that you should rerun your
program again (if you use debugger you co=
uld simply not pointed out
when some data changed and in the System.out cas=
e you can figure out
that you need more System.outs).

From the paragraph a=
bove one should conclude that when one write unit
test there is 2 different=
 phases. First is to write them down in the
hope that everything will be ok=
 (it doesn't mean, that you design
should be poor or you shouldn't supply a=
ppropriate messages to assert
statements etc) and the second phase is to re=
run your test if your
test fails. Lets see how logging will help you.

In t=
he first phase I see the only purpose using logs is for 'sanity
check' that=
 is to ensure that you actually test what your think is you
test. If you wa=
nt to make something more than just 'sanity check' you
should write unit te=
st to your unit test, that is pretty silly.
Moreover, you need to make such=
 'sanity check' only when you actually
write this test.  For this purpose l=
ogging is appropriate approach, IMHO.

In the second phase, when you rerun =
your unit test when it fails, you
should consider to add more assert statem=
ent and more clearly
diagnostic messages first. When you done and you don't=
 see how to
improve the design (recall I consider that design is correct) y=
ou can
add log statement manually. But in this case they will not be part o=
f
new mechanism, because no more asserts will be added. So this new
feature=
 will not be in use!

Using logging in the assert statement ONLY for 'sanit=
y check' is
overkill, I think. As for me I make such 'sanity check' in the
=
following way. First of all, I use log4j MANUALLY that is as addition
to JU=
nit asserts. They don't duplicate what asserts does they supply
additional =
information, such as what assertion was already done. In
this case when ass=
ertion will fail afterwards I can look on the log to
see in what part of un=
it test it happened and what tests passed. I go
even further and use JDK 1.=
4 assert statement to document
precondition, postcondition and invariants b=
oth in the code and in the
unit test.

The bottom line is that I see the se=
nse using logs as a COMPLETION to
the JUnit and only for 'sanity check'. Th=
is use is not duplicates
JUnit assert statements and could be written manua=
lly.
